messageBody:
## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for August 24, 2016 - August 30, 2016
##
## Message Issue Date: 2016-08-31T21:41:15Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2016-08-24T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2016-08-30T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20160831-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at very low levels during this reporting period.  There was 1 C-type CME (see details below).   

Geomagnetic activity was at minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=5 for the reporting period.  The highest value of Kp=5 occurred during the synoptic periods of 2016-08-23T18:00Z to 2016-08-24T03:00Z and was associated with a coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR at L1 around 2016-08-23.  

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 10^5 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this week.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
2016-08-30T03:12Z     ~585            C               -82/-7                13                          SOHO, STEREO A                    
 

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2016-08-31T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2016-09-06T23:59Z

The solar and geomagnetic activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week.  Currently, we are under the influence of a coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR at L1 around 2016-08-30 that could increase geomagnetic activity.  

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score


NASA GSFC Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC, http://swrc.gsfc.nasa.gov ) Disclaimer

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for August 17, 2016 - August 23, 2016
##
## Message Issue Date: 2016-08-25T18:39:46Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2016-08-17T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2016-08-23T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20160825-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at very low levels with only B class flares and no CMEs with speeds greater than 500 km/s during this reporting period.     

Geomagnetic activity was at below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=5 for the reporting period.  There was an increase in the solar wind speed observed by DSCOVR at L1 on 2016-08-21 and again on 2016-08-23. Consequently, the Kp index reached 4 from 2016-08-21T15:00Z - 18:00Z and later reached 5 during the synoptic periods 2016-08-23T18:00Z to 2016-08-24T03:00Z.  

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 10^5 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this week.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
None Observed  

CMEs (>500 km/s):
Earth directed:
None Observed  

Non-Earth directed:
None Observed 

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2016-08-24T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2016-08-30T23:59Z

The solar and geomagnetic activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week.  A high speed stream was observed at STEREO A on 2016-08-22 and is expected to arrive near Earth around 2016-09-01 to 2016-09-02 and could produce some below minor to minor geomagnetic activity.

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score


NASA GSFC Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC, http://swrc.gsfc.nasa.gov ) Disclaimer

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for August 10, 2016 - August 16, 2016
##
## Message Issue Date: 2016-08-17T20:42:22Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2016-08-10T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2016-08-16T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20160817-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period.  There were 2 C-type CMEs (see details below).   Based on preliminary heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA GSFC Space Weather Research Center, it was estimated that the CME starting at 2016-08-15T17:36Z may impact Spitzer around 2016-08-17T23:22Z (plus minus 7 hours) (see notification 20160815-AL-001).  

Geomagnetic activity was at below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=4 for the reporting period.

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt crossed the threshold level of 10^5 pfu on 2016-08-11T17:45Z and again on 2016-08-13T13:55Z.  These two events of elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt detected by GOES 13 were associated with the coronal hole high speed stream detected by ACE/DSCOVR on 2016-08-09 (see notifications 20160811-AL-001 and 20160813-AL-001).  

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low to moderate this week due to the events of increased electron fluxes in the outer radiation belt described above.  

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
2016-08-12T19:09Z     ~505            C               161/-4                16                          STEREO A                          
2016-08-15T17:36Z     ~750            C              -107/16                20                          SOHO, STEREO A                    
 

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2016-08-17T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2016-08-23T23:59Z

The solar and geomagnetic activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week.  Active regions on the solar disk appear to have low magnetic complexity.  Currently, the magnetic field at Earth appears to be disturbed due to a sector boundary crossing.  A coronal hole high speed stream is also expected to arrive in a couple of days by 2016-08-19.  

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - CME (Spitzer)
##
## Message Issue Date: 2016-08-15T23:51:03Z
## Message ID: 20160815-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

C-type CME detected by STEREO A / SOHO. 

Start time of the event: 2016-08-15T17:36Z.

Estimated speed: ~750 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 20 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): -107/16 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates (see [1] in Notes).

Activity ID: 2016-08-15T17:36:00-CME-001

Based on preliminary heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA GSFC Space Weather Research Center, it is estimated that the CME may impact Spitzer.  The leading edge of the CME will reach Spitzer at 2016-08-17T23:22Z (plus minus 7 hours). 

Links to the movies of the modeled event (includes CME(s): 2016-08-15T17:36:00-CME-001):

http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20160815_221100_2.0_anim.tim-den.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20160815_221100_2.0_anim.tim-vel.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20160815_221100_2.0_anim.tim-den-Stereo_A.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20160815_221100_2.0_anim.tim-den-Stereo_B.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20160815_221100_2.0_anim.tim-vel-Stereo_A.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20160815_221100_2.0_anim.tim-vel-Stereo_B.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20160815_221100_2.0_ENLIL_CONE_timeline.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20160815_221100_2.0_ENLIL_CONE_STA_timeline.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20160815_221100_2.0_ENLIL_CONE_STB_timeline.gif


## Notes: 

[1] http://iswawiki.gsfc.nasa.gov/wiki/index.php/Glossary/Heliospheric_Earth_Equatorial_coordinates

SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Radiation Belt Enhancement
##
## Message Issue Date: 2016-08-13T14:17:47Z
## Message ID: 20160813-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt. GOES 13 "greater than 0.8 MeV" integral electron flux is above 10^5 pfu starting at 2016-08-13T13:55Z. 

The elevated energetic electron flux levels are caused by a high speed stream starting at 2016-08-09T08:57Z.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2016-08-13T13:55:00-RBE-001. 

## Notes:

Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt. GOES 13 "greater than 0.8 MeV" integral electron flux is above 10^5 pfu starting at 2016-08-11T17:45Z. 

The elevated energetic electron flux levels are caused by high speed stream starting on 2016-08-09.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2016-08-11T17:45:00-RBE-001.

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for August 03, 2016 - August 09, 2016
##
## Message Issue Date: 2016-08-11T02:56:53Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2016-08-03T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2016-08-09T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20160811-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low to moderate levels during this reporting period with 1 M-class flare (see list below).  There were 2 C-type CMEs (see details below).   

Geomagnetic activity was at minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=5 for the reporting period.  The highest value of Kp=5 occurred during the synoptic periods of 2016-08-02T21:00Z to 2016-08-03T03:00Z and 2016-08-03T06:00Z-09:00Z.  This slight elevation of geomagnetic activity was associated with the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR at L1 around 2016-08-03.  The solar wind speed reached 725 km/s on 2016-08-05.  Second arrival of coronal high speed stream was detected around 2016-08-09.  The highest solar wind speed observed was around 685 km/s on 2016-08-09.  


The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt crossed the threshold level of 10^5 pfu starting at 2016-08-06T13:30Z.  This elevation in the energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt detected by GOES 13 was associated with the coronal hole high speed stream described above (see notifications 20160806-AL-001 and 20160806-AL-002).  

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low to moderate this week due to the elevation in the energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt. 


##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
2016-08-07  14:37:00  14:48:00  14:44:00   M1.3   S10W90         

CMEs (>500 km/s):
Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
2016-08-06T03:24Z     ~550            C                95/-2                10                          SOHO                              
2016-08-08T21:17Z     ~710            C                93/0                 22                          SOHO                              
 

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2016-08-10T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2016-08-16T23:59Z

The solar and geomagnetic activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week.  There are several active region on the solar disk that can produce flares and coronal mass ejections.  Geomagnetic activity is currently below minor levels but solar wind speeds are still elevated due to the arrival of the coronal hole high speed stream detected on 2016-08-09.

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Radiation Belt Enhancement
##
## Message Issue Date: 2016-08-06T15:44:09Z
## Message ID: 20160806-AL-002
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt. GOES 13 "greater than 0.8 MeV" integral electron flux is above 10^5 pfu starting at 2016-08-06T13:30Z. 

The elevated energetic electron flux levels are caused by the elevated solar wind velocity seen at ACE..

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2016-08-06T13:30:00-RBE-001.

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for July 27, 2016 - August 02, 2016
##
## Message Issue Date: 2016-08-03T20:23:07Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2016-07-27T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2016-08-02T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20160803-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period.  There was 1 C-type CME (see details below).   Based on preliminary heliospheric analysis and modeling carried out at NASA GSFC Space Weather Research Center, it was estimated that the CME starting on 2016-07-28T22:24Z (speed ~350 km/s) may have an impact on NASA missions near Earth between 2016-08-01 and 2016-08-02. The event was associated with a solar complex filament eruption and the transient was predicted to interact and merge with another approaching high speed solar wind stream region (see notification 20160729-AL-001).  The transient was detected by ACE at L1 around 2016-08-02T04:18Z (see notification 20160802-AL-001), and the coronal hole high speed stream arrived on 2016-08-03.  

Geomagnetic activity was at below moderate levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=5 for the reporting period.  The highest value of Kp=5 occurred at the end of the reporting period during the synoptic periods of 2016-08-02T21:00Z to 2016-08-03T03:00Z.  This slight elevation could be associated with the arrival of the CME and high speed stream described above. 

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 10^5 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this week.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  

CMEs (>500 km/s):
Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
2016-07-30T17:48Z     ~525            C              -168/14                33                          SOHO, STEREO A                    
 

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2016-08-03T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2016-08-09T23:59Z

The solar and geomagnetic activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week.  Former active regions 12565 and 12567, located on the far side of the Sun, can produce flares and coronal mass ejections.  Geomagnetic activity is currently elevated due to the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream detected by ACE at L1 on 2016-08-03.  Solar wind speeds are expected to remain elevated for the next few days.  

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - CME Arrival
##
## Message Issue Date: 2016-08-02T14:13:32Z
## Message ID: 20160802-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

CME Arrival detected by ACE/DSCOVR at L1 at 2016-08-02T04:18Z. 

The arrival is associated with a CME with ID 2016-07-28T22:24:00-CME-001 (see notification(s) 20160729-AL-001).  Strong magnetospheric compression and geomagnetic storm are possible. 

Activity ID: 2016-08-02T04:18:00-IPS-001.
